alert.note: Alert for Holmes; Wayne (Ohio) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued March 07 at 9:21PM EST until March 12 at 1:00AM EST by NWS Cleveland
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Ohio... Eagle Creek At Phalanx Station affecting Trumbull County. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Ohio... Scioto River Near Larue affecting Marion County. Nimishillen Creek Near North Industry affecting Stark County. Killbuck Creek Near Killbuck affecting Holmes and Wayne Counties. Mahoning River At Youngstown affecting Mahoning and Trumbull Counties. Black River At Elyria affecting Lorain County. Eagle Creek Above Findlay affecting Hancock County. For the Black River...including Elyria...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Scioto River...including Larue, Prospect...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Nimishillen Creek...including North Industry...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Mahoning River...including Leavittsburg, Warren, Youngstown...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Eagle Creek (Hancock)...including Findlay...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Eagle Creek (Trumbull)...including Phalanx Station...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY SATURDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Killbuck Creek Near Killbuck. * WHEN...Until early Saturday morning. * IMPACTS...At 17.0 feet, Private property on Water Street in the Village of Killbuck flooded. Several county and local roads impassable including State Route 60 south and County Road 621. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:00 PM EST Monday the stage was 16.5 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:00 PM EST Monday was 16.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 16.9 feet tomorrow morning. It will then fall below flood stage Friday evening. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Stay tuned to further developments by listening to your local radio, television, or NOAA Weather Radio for further information. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued Tuesday morning by 730 AM EST.
